contentrichtext.text: '''Economic militarism''' is the [[ideology]] surrounding the use of [[military]] expenditure to prop up an [[Economic system|economy]], or the use of military power to gain control or access to territory or other economic resources. ==Brief history of the term== The first important use{{Citation needed|date=November 2008}} dates from 1939 with ''Germany Rampant: A Study in Economic Militarism'' by Ernest Hambloch,<ref>{{Cite book|first=Ernest |last=Hambloch |year=1939 |title=Germany Rampant: A Study in Economic Militarism |publisher=Carrick & Evans |location=New York |oclc=1237438}}{{Page needed|date=September 2010}}</ref> a long-serving British diplomat.{{Citation needed|date=November 2008}} ''Germany Rampant'' "traces the philosophy of Nazism to the German mythological figures of ancient times."<ref>{{Cite web|publisher=[[United States Department of Labor]] |title=Holocaust: A selected bibliography of materials | location=[[Wirtz Labor Library]] Collection |url=http://www.dol.gov/oasam/library/bib/holobib.htm |accessdate=2008-11-25}}</ref> Since this book the term has been used in connection with the ancient [[Aztecs]], and with militaristic movements in a variety of cultures, and applies to the ideological and cultural aspects of a state, society or group that sustain the drive for [[hegemony]] or [[empire]]. For example Joseph Kenney applies the term to the [[Almoravids]].<ref>{{Cite book|first=Joseph |last=Kenney |chapter=The Economic Dimension of West African Islamic History |chapterurl=http://www.diafrica.org/kenny/Econom.htm |editor=Association of Episcopal Conferences of Anglophone West Africa |title=Christianity and Islam in dialogue |publisher=Mfantsiman Press |location=[[Cape Coast]] |year=1987 |isbn=978-978-30367-0-3 |oclc=30117272}}</ref> In 2003 [[Clyde Prestowitz]], of the Economic Strategy Institute published a book containing his analysis of what he called economic militarism in American foreign policy, that was reviewed in [[The Economist]] magazine.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2003-08-07 |title=American power |journal=[[The Economist]] |url=http://www.economist.com/printedition/displaystory.cfm?story_id=1973933 |format=Subscription only |accessdate=2008-11-25}}</ref> ==See also== * [[Militarism]] * [[Military Keynesianism]] * [[Military-industrial complex]] * [[Permanent war economy]] * [[War economy]] * [[Immanuel Wallerstein]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Economic Militarism}} [[Category:Military terminology]] [[Category:Political economy]] [[Category:Military economics]] [[Category:Military-industrial complex]] {{Mil-stub}} {{Econ-policy-stub}}
